CatDescriptText: Mr. Robert (Bob) Rogers, candy salesman, Homewood and Mr. Martin Brown, janitor, Fifth Ward, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, March 18, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think Negroes in Pittsburgh are as progressive as those in other metropolitan cities like New Your, Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland, San Francisco, and Los Angeles? Why?"  Mr. Rogers' answer reads: "No, not as progressive as those in other cities, but I think we're coming along.  We here, perhaps in the past, have been a little lazy."  Mr. Brown's answer reads: "Sure...For instance, in jobs, there are Negroes here with pretty good jobs and who are doing pretty good."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Robert "Bob" Rogers wearing eyeglasses and flecked overcoat, standing in front of house with screen door; Portrait of Martin Brown wearing dark fedora and tweed overcoat, standing on sidewalk with cars and buildings in background
